metadata.title: Polyurethane/graphite nano-platelet composites for thermal energy storage

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Renewable Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/renene
Polyurethane/graphite nano-platelet composites for thermal energy storage
Kinga Pielichowska*, Jakub Bieda, Piotr Szatkowski AGH University of Science and Technology, Faculty of Materials Science and Ceramics, Department of Biomaterials, Al. Mickiewicza 30, 30-059 Krak ow, Poland
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 28 January 2015 Received in revised form 17 January 2016 Accepted 24 January 2016 Available online xxx
Keywords: Phase change materials Polyurethanes Graphite nano-platelets Thermal energy storage
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: kingapie@agh.edu.pl (K. Pielichow
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2016.01.076 0960-1481/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
In this work new polyurethane-based phase change materials containing segments of poly(ethylene glycol) with average molar mass of 8000 g/mol with and without chain extender and modified with graphite nano-platelets have been fabricated and characterized. Structure, morphology and phase behaviour of these solid-solid phase change materials were investigated, as well as the thermal stability and conductivity. The heat of phase transition was in the range of 118.0e164.5 J/g for polyurethane without chain extender and 128.0e148.5 J/g for polyurethane with chain extender. The highest heat of phase transition and crystallinity were found for system modified with 0.3% of graphite nano-platelets in polyurethane without chain extender. Modulated differential scanning calorimetry results showed some changes in the phase transition behaviour and the crystallinity of the polyurethane matrix due to graphite nano-platelets confinement effect. Enhancements in the thermal stability in polyurethane modified with graphite nano-platelets, attributed to the barrier effect, were found based on thermogravimetric analysis data. The thermal conductivity increased with an increase of graphite nano-platelets content for both polyurethane systems, with and without chain extender, which is important for modern thermal energy storage applications.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Thermal energy storage in the form of latent heat is one of the most efficient methods for thermal energy storage. Due to high storage density and almost constant temperature during phase transition phase change materials (PCMs) are widely used for storing thermal energy [1,2]. Poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) is considered as one of the most promising PCMs as it is characterized by high phase change enthalpy, non-corrosiveness, adjustable phase change temperature and ease of chemical modification [3]. Properties of PEG for application as a PCM depend on average molecular weight and its crystallization behaviour. Depending on averagemolecular weight themelting point of PEGmay vary from 1 to 69 C, whereby the heat of melting lies in the range of 165e189 J/ g. Generally, PEG is a semi-crystalline thermoplastic polymer containing in the solid state both amorphous and crystalline regions in different proportions, depending upon the synthesis and thermal history [4]. However, the main problem with application of PEG as
ska).
PCM is leakage above its melting temperature due to solid-liquid phase transition. To avoid this problem, different methods of PEG shape stabilization were described in literature. Ding and coworkers modified PEG with cellulose diacetate (CDA) by chemical reaction and physical blending methods and they concluded that chemically linked materials were solid-solid PCMs while blended materials were solid-liquid PCMs [5]. Guo et al. [6]] investigated systems obtained by mixing of PEG with CDA in acetone and detected the solid-solid phase transition when the PEG fraction within the composite was less than 85%. Cellulose-graft-poly(ethylene glycol) copolymers showed solidesolid phase-transition behaviour with a high thermal storage density and good thermal stability too [7]. In other cellulose or cellulose derivative blends with PEG solid-solid phase transitions have been also observed at some concentrations [8,9], as well as in shape-stabilized PEG-based PCMs with polysaccharides, such as potato starch [10]. Shape stabilization effect was also observed in numerous copolymers of vinyl monomers with PEG such as poly(decaglycerol-co-PEG) [11], poly(styrene-graft-PEG) [12], poly(glycidyl methacrylate)-co-PEG [13] or PEG/poly(methyl methacrylate) blend [14] and PEG/epoxy composites [15]. An alternative approach is chemical linking of PEG
with polyisocyanates to obtain polyurethanes (PU) offering advantageous performance properties and ease of processing. The PU chains are composed of hard and soft segments arranged alternately. The hard segments are made of structures derived from diisocyanates, urethane oligomers obtained from diisocyanates and low-molecular weight hydroxyl chain extenders, or urea oligomers produced with the use of diisocyanates and water or amino chain extenders. The soft segments are composed of oxyethylene groups or oxypropylene groups, in particular oxytetramethylene polyester polyols or polyesters e which make linear polyurethane more flexible [16]. Poly(ethylene glycol) is one of the possible substrates for soft segments synthesis and its chemical incorporation in PU chains makes it possible to obtain PCMs with solid-solid phase transition. Hence, Su and Liu [17] synthesized polymeric
solidesolid PCM composed of high molecular weight PEG as soft segment, 4,40-diphenylmethane diisocyanate (MDI) and 1,4- butanediol (BDO) as a chain extender. Their results indicated solidesolid phase transition, suitable transition temperature, high transition enthalpy and good thermal stability. Li and Ding prepared solidesolid PCM via the condensation reaction of PEG 10000 with tetrafunctional pentaerythritol isocyanate [18].
On the other hand, carbon-based materials and nanomaterials were used in PCMs to improve thermal conductivity and for shape stabilization. Form-stable composite PCMs were prepared by vacuum impregnation of paraffin within graphene oxide (GO) sheets and thermal conductivity of the composite PCM was considerably improved from 0.305 to 0.985W/mK [19]. In thework by Qi [20] GO sheets were introduced to PEG to obtain shape stabilized PCM. Authors found that a maximumweight percentage of PEG was 96% without any leakage and the heat of phase transition of the composite obtained was 142.8 J/g.
In this paper new polyurethane/graphite nano-platelet composites displaying solidesolid and solid-liquid transitions were prepared by one step bulk polymerization method using PEG with average molar mass 8000 as a soft segments and MDI as a diisocyanate. Polyurethanes have been synthesized with or without 1,4- butanediol as chain extender and subjected to differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), modulated differential scanning calorimetry (TOPEM DSC), thermogravimetry (TG), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and optical microscopy (OM) investigations. The influence of graphite nano-platelets (GNP) on the thermal conductivity of PU composites has been investigated, too.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and synthesis
sections.text:
Polyurethane PCMs were obtained by a one-step bulk polymerization process. Poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) with average molecular weight 8000 was used as a soft segment, 1,4-butanediol (BDO) as a chain extender and 4,40-diphenylmethane diisocyanate (MDI) as a hard segment component in stoichiometric amounts. For the PUPEG samples molar ratio PEG:MDI was 1:1, for PUPEG_BDO samples molar ratio PEG:MDI:BDO was 1:2:1. All reagents were supplied from Sigma-Aldrich and were used as received without further purification. Graphite nano-platelets were supplied from Graphene Supermarket, USA; Grade AO-4 with the following producer specification: specific surface area <15 m/g2, purity 98.5%, average flake thickness 60 nm and particle lateral size ~ 3e7 microns. Poly(ethylene glycol) was dried under vacuum at the temperature of 110 C for 2 h. Graphite nano-platelets were introduced to the dry and melted PEG and dispersed by sonication. MDI

were introduced to PEG/GNP (or PEG/graphite nano-platelets/BDO) system and stirred. In the systems with chain extender BDO was introduced to the melted PEG just before synthesis. Next, the reactionmixturewas put on Petri dish, degassed, heated for 2 h at the temperature 100 C and then for 8 h at 80 C. The GNP content in the PUPEG varied from 0.3 to 4 wt. % (0.3, 0.5, 1, 2 and 4 wt. % of graphite nano-platelets). The composites without BDO were
denoted as PUPEG_xG, with BDO as PUPEG_BDO_xG, where x is GNP content in wt. %.

sections.heading: 2.2. Measurements
sections.text:
Infrared spectra were recorded under vacuum at room temperature using a horizontal attenuated total reflectance (ATR) attachment with ZnSe crystal on a Vertex 70v (Bruker) Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer in the range of 4000e550 cm 1 at a resolution of 2 cm 1. For the DSC measurements DSC1 (Mettler Toledo) operating in dynamic mode, was employed. Sample of ca. 6 mg weight was placed in sealed aluminium pan. The heating rate of 10 K/min and cooling rate of 10 K/min were applied; nitrogen was used as an inert gas. For TOPEM DSC measurements the underlying heating rate was 0.5 K/ min, the amplitude of the temperature pulse was ±0.5 K, and the switching time range to limit the duration of the pulses had the minimum of 15 s and the maximum of 50 s. Sample of ca. 15 mg weight was placed in sealed aluminium pans. Nitrogen with flow rate 30 ml/min was used as inert gas, and the intracooler was used for cooling. Prior to use the calorimeter was calibrated with an indium and mercury standards; an empty aluminium panwas used as reference.
The degree of crystallinity (Xc) of PUPEG was calculated based on the following relationship:
XC ¼ DHm
ð1 wÞ$DH0m $100% (1)
where DHm is the measured heat of fusion of PUPEG sample, DHm0 is the heat of fusion of 100% crystalline PEG (196.8 J/g [21]), and w is the weight fraction of GNP in the polymer matrix. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed using a Netzsch STA 449 Jupiter thermal analyzer, operating in a dynamic mode in the range 20e600 C at a heating rate of 10 K/min. The conditions were: sample weight, about 9 mg; atmosphere, nitrogen; punctured aluminium pan. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) Nova Nano SEM 200, equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray analyser (Link ISIS-EDX), was applied to investigate the surface morphology of carbon-coated samples at the energy of the electron beam of 5 kV. For optical microscopy observations micro-LAB 2.0 apparatus
(Pentagram) was employed. Thermal conductivity measurements were performed by comparison of heat flow through the investigated and reference samples according to ASTM E1225-87 standard. Scheme of in-house built equipment is presented in Fig. 1 and for calculation of the thermal conductivity the following relationship was applied:
lx ¼ lr$DTr DTx $ Dlx Dlr $ DSr DSx $K (2)
where: lx, lr e thermal conductivity of sample and reference, respectively; DTr e average temperature difference between the references; DTx e temperature difference in the sample, Dlr e average distance between the thermocouples in the reference; D lx e distance between the thermocouples in the sample; DSr e average contact area between sample and reference, DSx e surface of the test sample remaining in contact with reference, K e correction coefficient (K ¼ 2).
Thermal conductivity was determined under stationary heat flow conditions by measuring the temperature difference between the investigated sample and the reference samples. As reference samples copper plate with size 30 mm 10 mm 3 mm and thermal conductivity of 382 W/mK were applied. The investigated sample had the same size as reference samples. First, the furnace was heated up to 50 C and after the thermal equilibrium was achieved (after ca. 30 min) the temperature from thermocouples was read.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
FTIR spectra of obtained polyurethane composites are shown in Fig. 2 and description of characteristic absorption bands for PUPEG and PUPEG_BDO systems with different GNP content is given in Table 1.
The absorption band in the range 1145e1058 cm 1,
characteristic for ethers, is caused by asymmetric stretching vibrations of CeOeC group. The band located at ca. 3330 cm 1 is due to the presence of NeH stretching vibrations. Bands at ca. 1726 cm 1 originate from the presence of stretching vibrations of carbonyl group in urethane group. They are relatively weak due to small content of urethane groups in polyurethane structure which is a consequence of high average molar mass of PEG that was used as a soft segment. For PUPEG samples a band at 2945e2855 cm 1 is assigned to asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of CH2 group. Backbone vibrations causing stretch of the CeC bonds within aromatic ring absorb radiation in the range of 1598 cm 1 and 1466 cm 1. Radiation at wavenumber 1600 and 1222 cm 1 absorbs stretching vibration of CeN groups, and at 1535 cm 1 bending vibrations of NeH group. These results prove that the urethane bond (eNHCOOe) has been formed in the materials under investigation [22].
In the next stage the phase change behaviour of PUPEG and PUPEG_BDO materials was studied by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The DSC profiles of PUPEG and PUPEG_BDO as well as composites modified with GNP are presented in Fig. 3, and the temperature and heat of phase transition values are summarized in Table 2. Crystallinity degree of PEG in polyurethanematrix has been calculated too and is given in Table 3.
Generally, the temperatures of phase transition are slightly lower than those of pristine PEG 8000e for PEGwith averagemolar mass 6000e10000 melting temperature is ca. 65 C with heat of melting in the range of 170e190 J/g [2,22]. In the crystalline state, PEG has a helical structure with seven CH2CH2O units in two turns of the helix with a crystallographic repeat distance of 19.3 Å while the molten PEG loses this helical structure and consists of random (CH2eCH2eO) coils [23,24]. After polymerization with MDI, PEG chains are connected via chemical bond and forms longer polymer chains that loose their mobility and as a result their ability to crystallization get lower.
As it can be seen from data collected in Table 2, the obtained materials are characterized by quite high heat of phase transition, such as 164.4, 157.0 and 148.5 J/g for PUPEG_0.3G, PUPEG_0.5 and PUPEG_BDO_0.5, respectively. It should be noted that introduction of GNP in small amounts leads to an increase of heat of phase transition due to nucleation effect of GNP [25]. Further increasing of GNP content leads to a decrease of crystallinity and heat of phase transition due to hindered crystallization of macromolecules between the GNP because of the confinement effect. Müller et al. [26] investigated different polymer matrices and carbon nanotubes as nano-filler and postulated that confinement is created at high nano-filler loadings due to interactions between the polymer chains and the extremely large surface area of carbon nanotubes.
They found in nanocomposites a clear competition between nucleation and confinement effect and concluded that the polymer chain behaviour is dominated by one or the other depending on the nano-filler content; at low carbon nanotube contents the nucleation is dominating process, while for higher nano-filler content confinement of polymer chain between nanoparticles prevails. The latter effect causes reduction of the degree of crystallinity and melting and crystallization temperature, as well as an increase of the supercooling. For lower GNP concentration (below 1%) probably nucleation of polymer chains on GNP dominates but introduction of higher amounts of graphite leads to confinement of polymer chains between nano-platelets. Due to the relatively low surface area introduction of higher amounts of graphite that 5% was impossible e after sonication of graphite in melted PEG the viscosity was too high to perform synthesis with MDI. Generally, nanoscale confinement is observed when the properties of confined material deviate substantially from the bulk material. In polymer nanocomposites, in which the nanofiller load is several volume percent polymer is nanoconfinement [27]. As it can be seen from the shape of DSC curves for samples with larger amount of GNP two partially overlapping peaks are visible that means that PEG crystallize in two different forms with different melting temperatures depending on chains location - bulk or confined.
Crystallinity of polymeric samples depends on the nucleation
efficiency and usually the highest degree of crystallinity is obtained for nucleation agent content up to 1% e this agree with our results in which the highest degree of crystallinity was determined for samples with 0.3% of GNP for PUPEG and 0.5% for PUPEG_BDO. At higher content of graphite chain mobility is restricted and crystallization degree decreases due to confinement effects.
More information about the thermal behaviour of polymer composites can be obtained by using temperature-modulated differential scanning calorimetry with stochastic temperature modulations (TOPEM® DSC). Modulated differential scanning calorimetry offers the possibility to separate complex transitions in form of reversing and non-reversing heat flow signals and directly measure heat capacity changes from a single experiment [28,29]. In TOPEM DSC stochastic temperature modulations consist of temperature pulses, of fixed magnitude and alternating sign, with random durations within limits which are superimposed on the underlying rate of a conventional DSC scan. The temperature modulation allows frequency-dependent phenomena to be distinguished from frequency-independent phenomena in a single run [30]. TOPEM DSC traces after separation to reversing and nonreversing heat flow components are presented in Fig. 4.
For PUPEG_0G system one sharp melting peak can be observed in total heat flow, while in non-reversing heat flow strong exothermic effect that can be attributed to recrystallization of less
perfect crystals and next complete melting occurs. In reversing heat flow endothermic effect that originates from reversible melting can be found. For PUPEG_BDO_0G system one broad melting peak can be found, however, with much smaller recrystallization effect on the non-reversing curve. That suggests formation of more perfect crystals and probably some changes in the chain mobility due to introduction BDO in polymer chain. It should be noted that for systems with BDO as a chain extender melting point is above 60 C while for systems without BDO melting point is lower than 60 C which also suggests that more perfect crystals are formed in BDO containing systems. For materials modified with GNP two melting
peaks in the total heat flow profile can be observed in PUPEG_BDO with 1 and 4 wt. % of GNP and in PUPEG with 4 wt. % of graphite nano-platelets. Recrystallization and reversible melting can be also detected. Double melting peak can be attributed to (i) melting of polymer crystals formed in confined space between graphite nanoplatelets, and, (ii) melting of bulk PEG. Depression of melting point of confined PEG chains was observed by other authors, too [31]. They revealed that confinement of PEG chains in carbon nanoparticles leads to the disappearance of crystallization and to a significant modification of the glass transition. Chain conformations of poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) confined in carbon nanoparticles are
distinctly different from those characteristic of the semicrystalline bulk, and similar to those of PEO confined in the interlayer space of graphite oxide. It was found that in case of graphene PEO chains adsorb firmly onto the graphene sheets, with a substantial increase in the population of gauche conformers. Using modulated DSC well-defined glass and melting transitions associated with the confined polymer phase were found at significantly lower temperatures than those of the bulk [32]. However, in our polyurethane systems at small graphene concentrations nucleating effect on graphene sheets still dominates and PEG crystallizes in spherulite form as it can be seen in Figs. 5 and 6. OM images show spherulites of about 1e5 mm for PUPEG_BDO_0.5G system with regions of lamellar crystal bundles which are integral components of spherulites radiating from the center of a spherulite. During PEG crystallization first homo- or heteronucleation (e.g. on GNP) takes place and next growth from the nuclei to form structures of spherulitic geometry is observed until the spreading fronts impinge on each other and as a result polyhedral structures are formed [33].
One can assume that graphite nano-platelets acts as a
nucleation site and three-dimensional shapes have been observed e images show that the spherulites are space-filled with no evidence of GNP inter-spherulitic accumulation.
SEM microphotographs (Fig. 6) show the lamellar structure of the spherulites which constitute the crystalline morphology of PUPEG composites.
More regular lamellar structures can be observed for PUPEG_BDO_1G which confirms that composites with lower GNP content are characterized by higher crystallinity and contain more perfect crystals. Higher GNP content causes some hindrances in PEG crystallization in polyurethane system and leads to lower degree of crystallinity of PEG in PUPEG/GNP composites in comparison to unmodified PUPEG and PUPEG with small amount of graphite. For polymers nucleating agents with different size are usually used (from nano to microscale) and the final effect depends mainly on the size and concentration of nucleating agent, as well as on polymer crystallization ability. The optimal concentration of nucleating agent has to be found for each polymer/nucleating agent system [34]. Too low concentration of nucleating agent does not
Table 4 Thermal stability of PUPEG composites.
Sample T1% [oC] T3% [oC] T5% [oC] T10% [oC] T20% [oC] T50% [oC] TDTGmax [ C] Char residue at 600 C [%]
PUPEG_BDO_0G 272 344 372 389 400 412 300 1.3 413 PUPEG_BDO_4G 282 365 379 391 400 413 253 9.5 414 PUPEG_0G 322 372 383 392 400 412 416 5.0 PUPEG_4G 337 369 380 391 400 412 413 5.9
lead to the desired effect of efficient crystallization, while too high concentration causes hindrances in crystallization and formation of less perfect crystals characterized by lower heat of melting and lower melting temperature. This kind of behavior was observed for various polymer nanocomposites [35e37].
Analysis of TG results indicates significantly lower thermal stability of PUPEG_BDO composites in comparison to PUPEG systems e Fig. 7, Table 4.
TG and DTG curves show two degradation steps for BDOcontaining systems and one degradation step for polyurethanes without BDO. For the PUPEG_BDO material maximum degradation rate (TDTGmax) for the first degradation step is about 300 C for unmodified sample and 253 C for system modified with 4% of graphite nano-platelets. In the first step mass loss is ca. 5% that corresponds to hard segment content in PUPEG_DBO systems. Maximum degradation rate in the second degradation step was at 413e414 C for both materials with BDO. For pristine PUPEG maximum degradation rate was found at 413 C and at 416 C for composite with 4% of graphite nano-platelets. According to literature data the first degradation step for BDO-containing materials can be attributed to hard segments degradation via depolycondensation [38], while the second degradation step is connected with degradation of soft segments by a radical decomposition of the polyol chain [39,40]. Introduction of graphite causes an increase in the thermal stability of PU matrix up to 10e15 C in both with and without BDO systems. Similar effect of graphene influence on polyurethane matrix stability was observed for functionalized graphene nanoplatelets/polyurethane system [41] and in PEG/graphene system [42]. Incorporation of graphene nano-platelets can
significantly reduce gas permeation through a polymer composite because percolating network of platelets can provide a ‘tortuous path’ which inhibits molecular diffusion through the matrix, thus resulting in significantly reduced permeability and barrier properties [43]. During thermal degradation graphene flakes or graphite nano-platelets hinder evolution of volatile decomposition products acting as a barrier and prevent the propagation of heat from the surroundings into the polymeric matrix - in consequence enhancements in the thermal stability are observed [44].
An undesirable feature of polymeric PCMs is their relatively low thermal conductivity that significantly decelerates the energy charging/discharging rates. Some attempts have been made to enhance the effective thermal conductivity of organic and polymeric PCMs such as incorporation of various forms of stationary metallic structures/inserts, e.g. fins or foams into the thermal energy storage systems. An alternative solution is the inclusion of highly-conductive particles to form composite PCMs [45,46]. To examine the influence of GNP introduction into polyurethanebased PCM the thermal conductivity has been measured e Fig. 8.
As shown in Fig. 8 the thermal conductivity increases with an increase of graphite content for both systems, with and without BDO. This effect is due to graphene high thermal conductivity. Graphene is a 2D carbon nanofiller with a one-atom-thick sheet of sp2 hybridization of carbon atoms that are densely packed in a honeycomb crystal lattice [47]. Single layer graphene is predicted to have a remarkable performance: at room temperature, the thermal conductivity of graphene has been measured to be almost 5000 W/ m K for a single layer [43,48e51] and approximately 600 W/m K when supported on a SiO2 substrate [43,52]. The graphene nanosheets planar structure can provide a 2-D path for phonon transport, and the ultrahigh surface area of graphene nanosheets allows a large contact area with polymer matrix resulting in a more significant enhancement of composite thermal conductivity than carbon nanotubes [50]. The graphene nanosheets can be functionalized and creates covalent bonds with different organic moieties needed as links with polymer chains. The grafting of polymers on graphene sheets could provide better dispersion and enhance strength and conductivity properties of new materials [53,54]. On the other hand functionalization of graphene nanosheets led to the production of defect sites within the conjugated graphene sheet structure, which decreased the conjugation within the graphene sheets, causing significant decrease on the inherent electrical and thermal conductivity [55].
Another approach is the non-covalent functionalization graphene nanosheets since this approach is based on Van der Waals force or pep interaction of aromatic molecules on the graphene nanosheets basal plane, that allow avoid generating defects [56,57]. Such approach was presented in the work by Teng et al. [55] where non-covalent functionalization was used to modify graphene nanosheets through pep stacking of pyrene molecules with a functional segmented polymer chain. Remarkable improvement in the thermal conductivity of graphene nanosheets-filled polymer composites was observed. In the case of PUPEG/graphene composites formation of pep complexes can occur, too. Li and Chen [58] by measuring the 13C spin-lattice relaxation times and 1H transverse relaxation times of the complex sample and by comparing the static 13C spectrum of the pure fullerene C60 sample which also is formed from aromatic carbon rings, with that of the complex sample, demonstrated pep interactions between the porbitals of the PEG ether oxygen and the p-system of C60. As PEG segments are present in the PUPEG copolymers, this kind of interactions may occur in the systems under consideration. As result the variation of thermal conductivity in different graphite containing PUPEG composites is related to the changes in the degree of crystallinity of the host polymer matrix and to the existence of
graphene percolation pathways for the charge carriers but also it is possible due to pep interactions between ether oxygen in soft segments and aromatic structures in graphene nanosheets [59].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In this work phase change materials based on polyurethane modified with GNP were synthesized using a one-step bulk polymerization method. DSC measurements revealed that the heat of phase transition was in the range of 118e164.5 J/g for PUPEG without BDO and 128e148.5 J/g for PUPEG with BDO. The highest heat of phase transitionwas found for systems modified with small amount of GNP (0.3e0.5 wt. % of graphite nano-platelets) suggesting that GNP acts as nucleating agents for PEG-based soft segments in PUPEG systems. From TOPEM DSC data it can be concluded that introduction of GNP changes phase transition behaviour and the crystallinity of the PU matrix. In OM images spherulites of about 1e5 mm were observed with regions of lamellar crystal bundles radiating from the center of a spherulite for all investigated systems. However, more regular lamellar structures can be observed for systems with lower GNP content. Enhancements in the thermal stability and thermal conductivity in PUPEG systems modified with GNP were found which is important for thermal energy storage applications.

referenceMentions.context: Due to high storage density and almost constant temperature during phase transition phase change materials (PCMs) are widely used for storing thermal energy [1,2].
Due to high storage density and almost constant temperature during phase transition phase change materials (PCMs) are widely used for storing thermal energy [1,2].

Poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) is considered as one of the most promising PCMs as it is characterized by high phase change enthalpy, non-corrosiveness, adjustable phase change temperature and ease of chemical modification [3].

Generally, PEG is a semi-crystalline thermoplastic polymer containing in the solid state both amorphous and crystalline regions in different proportions, depending upon the synthesis and thermal history [4].

Ding and coworkers modified PEG with cellulose diacetate (CDA) by chemical reaction and physical blending methods and they concluded that chemically linked materials were solid-solid PCMs while blended materials were solid-liquid PCMs [5].
[6]] investigated systems obtained by mixing of PEG with CDA in acetone and detected the solid-solid phase transition when the PEG fraction within the composite was less than 85%.
Cellulose-graft-poly(ethylene glycol) copolymers showed solidesolid phase-transition behaviour with a high thermal storage density and good thermal stability too [7].

In other cellulose or cellulose derivative blends with PEG solid-solid phase transitions have been also observed at some concentrations [8,9], as well as in shape-stabilized PEG-based PCMs with polysaccharides, such as potato starch [10].

Graphene is a 2D carbon nanofiller with a one-atom-thick sheet of sp2 hybridization of carbon atoms that are densely packed in a honeycomb crystal lattice [47].

Single layer graphene is predicted to have a remarkable performance: at room temperature, the thermal conductivity of graphene has been measured to be almost 5000 W/ m K for a single layer [43,48e51] and approximately 600 W/m K when supported on a SiO2 substrate [43,52].

The graphene nanosheets planar structure can provide a 2-D path for phonon transport, and the ultrahigh surface area of graphene nanosheets allows a large contact area with polymer matrix resulting in a more significant enhancement of composite thermal conductivity than carbon nanotubes [50].
The grafting of polymers on graphene sheets could provide better dispersion and enhance strength and conductivity properties of new materials [53,54].

As result the variation of thermal conductivity in different graphite containing PUPEG composites is related to the changes in the degree of crystallinity of the host polymer matrix and to the existence of graphene percolation pathways for the charge carriers but also it is possible due to pep interactions between ether oxygen in soft segments and aromatic structures in graphene nanosheets [59].

metadata.abstractText: In this work new polyurethane-based phase change materials containing segments of poly(ethylene glycol) with average molar mass of 8000 g/mol with and without chain extender and modified with graphite nano-platelets have been fabricated and characterized. Structure, morphology and phase behaviour of these solid-solid phase change materials were investigated, as well as the thermal stability and conductivity. The heat of phase transition was in the range of 118.0e164.5 J/g for polyurethane without chain extender and 128.0e148.5 J/g for polyurethane with chain extender. The highest heat of phase transition and crystallinity were found for system modified with 0.3% of graphite nano-platelets in polyurethane without chain extender. Modulated differential scanning calorimetry results showed some changes in the phase transition behaviour and the crystallinity of the polyurethane matrix due to graphite nano-platelets confinement effect. Enhancements in the thermal stability in polyurethane modified with graphite nano-platelets, attributed to the barrier effect, were found based on thermogravimetric analysis data. The thermal conductivity increased with an increase of graphite nano-platelets content for both polyurethane systems, with and without chain extender, which is important for modern thermal energy storage applications. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
